abstract.para: Monitor &SERVICENAME; to maintain reliability, availability, and performance.

chapter.para: Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, availability, and performance of &SERVICENAME; and your other &AWS; solutions. &AWS; provides the following monitoring tools to watch &SERVICENAME;, report when something is wrong, and take automatic actions when appropriate:

listitem.para: &CWlong; monitors your &AWS; resources and the applications you run on &AWS; in real time. You can collect and track metrics, create customized dashboards, and set alarms that notify you or take actions when a specified metric reaches a threshold that you specify. For example, you can have &CW; track CPU usage or other metrics of your &EC2; instances and automatically launch new instances when needed. For more information, see the &link-cw-user;.

&CWLlong; enables you to monitor, store, and access your log files from &EC2; instances, &CT;, and other sources. &CWL; can monitor information in the log files and notify you when certain thresholds are met. You can also archive your log data in highly durable storage. For more information, see the &link-cwl-user;.

&CTlong; captures API calls and related events made by or on behalf of your &AWS-account; and delivers the log files to an &S3; bucket that you specify. You can identify which users and accounts called &AWS;, the source IP address from which the calls were made, and when the calls occurred. For more information, see the &link-ct-user;.

chapter.para: &EVlong; is a serverless event bus service that makes it easy to connect your applications with data from a variety of sources. &EV; delivers a stream of real-time data from your own applications, Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) applications, and &AWS; services and routes that data to targets such as &LAM;. This enables you to monitor events that happen in services, and build event-driven architectures. For more information, see the &link-ev-user;.

section.para: You can monitor &SERVICENAME; using &CW;, which collects raw data and processes it into readable, near real-time metrics. These statistics are kept for 15 months, so that you can access historical information and gain a better perspective on how your web application or service is performing. You can also set alarms that watch for certain thresholds, and send notifications or take actions when those thresholds are met. For more information, see the &link-cw-user;.
For &SERVICENAME;, you might want to watch for XXX, and also watch XXX and Take Automatic Action when This Happens.
The &SERVICENAME; service reports the following metrics in the AWS/MyServiceName namespace.

entry.para: The volume of log events in uncompressed bytes uploaded to &CWL;. When used with the LogGroupName dimension, this is the volume of log events in uncompressed bytes uploaded to the log group.

section.para: The following dimensions are supported for the &SERVICENAME; metrics.

entry.para: The subscription destination for the &CWL; data, which can be &LAMlong;, &AKSlong;, or &AKFlong;.
